info.name: Oracle Identity Cloud Service Access Authentication API
info.description:
Customzing the log in experience with Oracle Identity Cloud Service has required that end users have 3-party cookies enabled in their browsers. This is a problem to many users, especially those providing B2C applications where they can't impose any controls on end-user behavior.

Oracle Identity Cloud Service has eliminated that dependency by introducing new authenticating APIs based on the concept of a state machine, where request responses inform an application client what has to be done next.

The requestState provided in each request response is used in the next request, providing the client with the information that it needs to process the request, and then provide the next set of operations allowed.

item.name: Authentication Without MFA
item.description: Test authentication using the user's credentials and the requestState without Multi-Factor Authentication.

item.name: Step 1: Authentication Request with AppName

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2, which is the user name/password.

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the user's credentials, which are the user name and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in Step 1 (this step).

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)
- scenario

item.name: Authentication Using User Name/Password + MFA Enrollment
item.description: Test authentication using the user's credentials, requestState, and enrolling in Multi-Factor Authentication.

item.name: Offline TOTP Enrollment
item.description:
A mobile app uses either OTP or push notifications to prove that the user has possession of the mobile device. Only the mobile app that is in possession of the user's secret key can generate a valid OTP. Provisioning the secret key can be done online or offline. 
 
This enrollment scenario is using the user's credentials, the requestState, and the offline MFA TOTP.
 
Identity Cloud Service users can use the OMA app or any supported third-party authenticator app that they want to generate OTPs. However, users must use the OMA app to receive push notifications. Use the Scan offline QR Code option to set up 3rd party authenticators.

item.name: Step 1: Authentication Request with no Tokens/Session

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the user name/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the user name and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

item.name: Step 2: User Name/Password Submission

request.description:
This step sends the user name and password and the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response.

In the response received during Step 2 
"nextOp": "enrollment" indicates that the user should enroll in MFA as the next step.

Note that BYPASSCODE is missing in the response since the user can't enroll using a Bypass Code. The Bypass Code should be generated by the user using My Profile or by requesting that an admin generate one for them.

The policy evaluation happens in the background and the next applicable operation (either enrollment or authentication) is sent in the response.

item.name: Step 3: Offline TOTP Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in the offline TOTP factor. The requestState that was received in the Step 2 response is included.

The requestState in the request contains the following information:

- deviceId
- authFactor
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid

For the Next Step:

The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response.

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:
You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 4.

item.name: Step 4: Offline TOTP Enrollment Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the factor credentials and the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response.

The otpCode attribute contains the passcode generated on the third-party code generator app.

The requestState in the request contains:

- deviceId
- authFactor

Because deviceId and authFactor are included in the requestState, the client doesn't need to send this information.

In the Response, 
"nextOp": "createToken", indicates that the client can now request a token.

The user can also choose to continue to enroll in other factors. Should the user continue to enroll, an extra call should be made to get the details of all factors (Get Backup Factors) that a user can enroll in.

Included in the requestState that is received in the response:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

The server validates that no other factors evaluation (depending on what is defined for the policy) is needed and responds with the token or denies access.

item.name: Step 3: Online TOTP Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in an online TOTP. The requestState that was received in the Step 2 response is included.

Note that there is no need to include credentials in the request, since the online TOTP is being used.

In the Response:

The requestState in the response contains the following information:
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

Note that the value for "content" always begins with "oraclemobileauthenticator//"

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:

You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 4.

item.name: Step 4: Online TOTP Enrollment Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

1) If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"nextop"="in_progress" (This nextop attribute appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"nextop"="completed" (This nextop attribute appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and the optCode verification is successful).

2) The client keeps polling if the "otpCode" = null every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- requestId
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

item.name: Step 4: PUSH Notification Enrollment Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

The requestState in the request contains:
- deviceId
- requestId
- authFactor

1) If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"nextop"="credSubmit" (if the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"nextop"="createToken" (if the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and otpCode verification is successful).

-"nextop"="setCookie" (if OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and otoCode verification is successful).

2) The client keeps polling every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

-deviceId
-requestId
-authFactor
-creationTime
-tenantName
-appName

item.name: Authentication Using Security Questions Factor When It Isn't the Default Method
item.description:
If a user wants to use Security Questions to log in, and if Security Questions aren't the default method, the user is required to make an additional request to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
The additional request is to obtain the backup methods available and the requestState.

In the response, locate the question to use as the security question backup method and the requestState.
 
Step 4
For security questions, use the question provided in the response from the request to obtain the backup methods, and then provide the answer and the requestState to get the access token.

item.name: Authentication Using Email Factor When It Isn't the Default Method
item.description:
If a user wants to use EMAIL to log in, and if EMAIL is not the default method, the user is required to make two requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
The first request is to obtain the backup methods available.

For email, locate the deviceId for Email provided in the response and the requestState.
 
Step 4 
The second request includes the OTP that the user receives through email. (This information can be extracted from the getBackupFactors call).

When the SDK receives a credSubmit on EMAIL, with the deviceId, it understands that it first needs to send an EMAIL with the OTP code.

item.name: Authenticating Using Offline TOTP When It Isn't the Default Method
item.description:
If a user wants to use TOTP to log in, and if TOTP isn't the default method, the user is required to make additional requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
This request is to obtain the backup methods available.

For TOTP, locate the deviceId for TOTP provided in the response and the requestState.
 
Step 4 
This request includes the deviceID, the otpCode (TOTP), and the requestState to authenticate.

item.name: Authenticating Using Online TOTP When It Isn't the Default Method
item.description:
If a user wants to use TOTP to log in, and if TOTP isn't the default method, the user is required to make additional requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
This request is to obtain the backup methods available.

For TOTP, locate the deviceId for TOTP provided in the response and the requestState.
 
Step 4 
This request includes the deviceID, the otpCode (TOTP), and the requestState to authenticate.

item.name: Authenticating Using SMS When It Isn't the Default Method
item.description:
If a user wants to use SMS to log in, and if SMS is not the default method, the user is required to make additional requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
This request is to obtain the backup methods available and the requestState.

In the response, locate the deviceId for SMS to use and the requestState.

Step 4
This request includes deviceId and the requestState to initate SMS. When the SDK receives a credSubmit on SMS, with the deviceId, it understands that it first needs to send an SMS with the OTP code.

Step 5
This request includes the OTP that the user received on their device in response to Step 4. Since a user account can have many phone numbers enrolled, the user needs to provide the deviceId when requesting access.

- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).
